main event: A bell-shaped object with a flame but no smoke or exhaust was observed descending vertically and then moving horizontally at a high rate of speed over Union, Maine on February 16, 1961.
interesting points: The object was observed by an ex-USAF pilot who compared its brilliance to that of burning magnesium.
The object was traveling low in a flat trajectory from east to west and went out of sight behind a barn and trees.
Weather conditions at the time included clear skies, a slight temperature inversion, and winds around 20-28 knots.
The Bangor Daily News reported numerous sightings of the object on the same night, stating it was visible from Portland.

The Air Force concluded the sighting was possibly a balloon or aircraft, but the object's behavior (vertical descent, high-speed horizontal movement) was not typical of known aerial vehicles at the time.
sighted object: bell-shaped object with a flame but no smoke or exhaust
